Subjective: Extreme fatigue past 2 months. Wakes up tired despite sleeping a lot. Possible superficial sleep. No clear trigger or acute onset. Still able to climb 2-3x/week and cycle without significant decrease in performance. Work is difficult, often feeling exhausted by end of day, but not yet called in sick. Increased muscle pain and back pain noted. Googled symptoms, considered rheumatism due to morning stiffness. Father has back issues. Occasional waking up startled (lifelong). Uses allergy medication for hay fever, which works well. No palpitations, chest pain, good appetite, stable weight (~72kg). Bowel movements daily, multiple times/day, 'soepel'. Urination normal. No other concerns.
Objective: BP: 110/60. HR: 40-50 bpm. Lungs: clear. Back exam: no specific tenderness on palpation of vertebrae, mild tenderness lower back paraspinal. No pain on pressure on pelvis. Back muscles massage feels good, no asymmetry. Neck ROM normal, no pain. Shoulders free. Abdomen: active bowel sounds, tympanic percussion, no tenderness on palpation. No gross abnormalities on exam.
Assessment: Fatigue of unknown origin. Differential diagnosis includes anemia, thyroid dysfunction, inflammatory conditions (rheumatism less likely given exam findings).
Plan: Blood tests: CBC (anemia), TSH (thyroid), inflammatory markers (ESR/CRP). Patient to have blood drawn. Results available day after draw. Schedule phone appointment day after results to discuss findings and next steps.
